question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_max_duration_within_thresholds_to_price_feed()] [Timer Manipulation] If max_duration_within_thresholds is changed while diff_threshold2_timer is active, can an attacker exploit timestamp arithmetic to extend or reset the anomaly window? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_max_duration_within_thresholds_to_price_feed()] [Zero Duration Attack] Can an attacker set max_duration_within_thresholds to 0, causing immediate rejection of any price between thresholds and creating DoS on legitimate price updates? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_allowed_span_percentage_to_price_feed()] [Span Bypass] Can an attacker set maximum_allowed_span_percentage to 0, bypassing span validation and allowing any price change magnitude? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_allowed_span_percentage_to_price_feed()] [Overflow in Span Calculation] Can an attacker set maximum_allowed_span_percentage to u64::MAX, causing overflow in percentage calculations (x * 10000) and bypassing span checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_allowed_span_percentage_to_price_feed()] [Basis Point Confusion] If maximum_allowed_span_percentage expects basis points (x * 10000) but an attacker sets raw percentage values, can this cause 100x larger spans than intended? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [Price Ceiling Removal] Can an attacker set maximum_effective_price to u256::MAX, effectively removing the price ceiling and allowing flash loan price manipulation to bypass bounds? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [Inversion Attack] Can an attacker set maximum_effective_price below the current minimum_effective_price, creating an invalid price range that rejects all prices? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_minimum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [Price Floor Removal] Can an attacker set minimum_effective_price to 0, allowing dust prices or underflow attacks to pass validation? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_minimum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [Narrow Price Range Attack] Can an attacker set minimum_effective_price very close to maximum_effective_price, creating a narrow valid range that causes legitimate price updates to be rejected? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_historical_price_ttl_to_price_feed()] [TTL Bypass] Can an attacker set historical_price_ttl to u64::MAX, causing the oracle to accept infinitely old historical prices and bypassing freshness checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_historical_price_ttl_to_price_feed()] [TTL Zero Attack] Can an attacker set historical_price_ttl to 0, causing all historical price lookups to immediately expire and forcing dependence on live prices that may be manipulatable? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_pyth_oracle_provider_config()] [Duplicate Provider] Can an attacker call create_pyth_oracle_provider_config multiple times for the same feed_id, creating duplicate provider configs and causing confusion in provider selection? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_pyth_oracle_provider_config()] [Invalid Pair ID] Can an attacker provide an empty or malformed pair_id vector, causing Pyth price lookups to fail silently or return incorrect prices? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_pyth_oracle_provider_config()] [Feed ID Mismatch] Can an attacker specify feed_id for asset A but pair_id for asset B, causing cross-asset price confusion when Pyth oracle is queried? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_pyth_price_oracle_provider_pair_id()] [Pair ID Swap] Can an attacker change the pair_id of an active primary Pyth provider to a different asset's pair, causing immediate price mismatch without disabling the provider? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_pyth_price_oracle_provider_pair_id()] [Malicious Pair ID] Can an attacker set pair_id to a manipulated or low-liquidity Pyth feed, redirecting price queries to attacker-controlled or easily manipulatable sources? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: enable_pyth_oracle_provider()] [Enable Without Validation] Can an attacker enable a Pyth provider with invalid or unconfigured pair_id, causing price queries to fail or return default values? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: disable_pyth_oracle_provider()] [Disable Primary Provider] Can an attacker disable the Pyth provider while it's set as primary, causing price feed queries to fail without automatic fallback to secondary? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: disable_pyth_oracle_provider()] [DoS Attack] Can an attacker disable all oracle providers for critical price feeds, causing vault operations to halt due to unavailable price data? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_supra_oracle_provider_config()] [Pair ID Type Confusion] Can an attacker exploit the conversion from u32 pair_id to vector<u8> via adaptor_supra::pair_id_to_vector to inject malformed pair identifiers? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_supra_oracle_provider_config()] [Provider Conflict] Can an attacker create both Pyth and Supra configs for the same feed_id with conflicting pair_ids, causing inconsistent prices depending on which provider is queried? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_supra_price_source_pair_id()] [Vector Injection] Can an attacker pass a vector<u8> that doesn't match Supra's expected pair ID format, causing price lookups to fail or return garbage data? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_supra_price_source_pair_id()] [Cross-Provider Attack] Can an attacker set Supra pair_id while the feed is using Pyth as primary, then switch providers to exploit pre-configured malicious Supra feed? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: enable_supra_oracle_provider()] [Unconfigured Provider] Can an attacker enable Supra provider before calling create_supra_oracle_provider_config, causing queries to fail with provider_config_not_found error? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: disable_supra_oracle_provider()] [Provider Switching Attack] Can an attacker disable Supra immediately after it's set as primary but before a price update, causing price queries to fail mid-operation? (High)
